review.title: Localization for Wireless Sensor Networks: A Neural Network Approach
review.abstract: As Wireless Sensor Networks are penetrating into the industrial domain, many research opportunities are emerging. One such essential and challenging application is that of node localization. A feed-forward neural network based methodology is adopted in this paper. The Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) values of the anchor node beacons are used. The number of anchor nodes and their configurations has an impact on the accuracy of the localization system, which is also addressed in this paper. Five different training algorithms are evaluated to find the training algorithm that gives the best result. The multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) neural network model was trained using Matlab. In order to evaluate the performance of the proposed method in real time, the model obtained was then implemented on the Arduino microcontroller. With four anchor nodes, an average 2D localization error of 0.2953 m has been achieved with a 12-12-2 neural network structure. The proposed method can also be implemented on any other embedded microcontroller system.

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijcnc.2016.8105 61 As wireless sensor networks penetrate into the industrial area, many research opportunities arise. One such essential and challenging application is the localization of nodes. In this paper, a methodology based on feed-forward neural networks is adopted; the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) value of anchor node beacons is used; the number of anchor nodes and their configurations influences the accuracy of the localization system, which is also addressed in this paper; five different training algorithms are evaluated to find the training algorithm that delivers the best result; the multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) model of neural networks has been trained with Matlab; in order to evaluate the performance of the proposed method in real time, the obtained model has been implemented on the Arduino microcontroller. With four anchor nodes, an average localization error of 253 was achieved.

sections.text: Consider the case when N number of sensor nodes is used in a sensor network with locations L = {L1, L2,..., LN}. Let Lxi, Lyi, Lzi specify the x, y and z coordinates of the th sensor node. The problem of node localization involves the determination of these locations and by allowing Lzi = 0 you get a problem with 2 dimensions. Sensor nodes with knowledge of their positions are known as anchors or beacons. All nodes in the network with unknown position localize themselves with the help of these anchor nodes. sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: An efficient 2D localization algorithm for WSN was proposed by the use of ANN. Different configurations of anchor nodes were evaluated, which can be used by the researchers in selecting the number of anchor nodes to be used depending on the application environment. Input into the proposed method is the RSSI values of the signal received by the anchor nodes. As all sensor nodes are equipped with RF modules for wireless communication, no external hardware is required. Therefore, the proposed method is energy efficient and uses only a double message to obtain the inputs for the localization. However, it is recommended that the RSSI value of the localization signals received by the anchor nodes is also used, which may lead to a further reduction of the localization error. To obtain the best neural network for localization, the BR training algorithm is evaluated to provide the best result of the localization signals received by the anchor nodes, which may lead to a further reduction of the localization error.
